headline.main: Comfort Foods Switch Off Stress, Scientists Find

docs.abstract: Dr Norman Pecoraro, University of California (San Francisco) postdoctoral fellow, publishes research in Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences online version, that shows that eating comfort foods blunts effects of stress on body; research, carried out on rats, finds that feeding chronically stressed rats sugar calms them down; also finds that people with more abdominal fat are better able to cope with and shut down chronic stress; abdominal fat, however, is also linked with higher rates of other life threatening diseases; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When life is not going so smoothly and people reach for goodies full of fat and sugar, they are doing more than surrendering to cravings. Comfort foods like chocolate cake and ice cream literally blunt the body's response to chronic stress, scientists reported last week. The finding, published in the online edition of The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, confirms what many people know firsthand. Eating calorie-rich food seems to calm the nerves, but eating too much can lead to obesity, depression and more stress.

headline.main: Exercise Is a Habit; Here's Why to Pick It Up

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses two new studies showing how physical activity benefits overall health and weight; Dr Anne McTiernan, Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center (Seattle) researcher, directs study that shows how risk of various life threatening conditions is reduced in direct proportion to increase in physical activity; study also finds that those women who take hormone replacements receive benefits of increased activity as well; Dr John M Jakicic of University of Pittsburgh's Physical Activity and Weight Management Research Center finds calorie reductions paired with exercise improved health and weight management, but neither degree of exercise intensity nor duration directly effected results; suggests that exercising moderately for one hour consistently each day is more effective than shorter or inconsistent sessions; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A strikingly large number of Americans have failed to catch the exercise bug, and the effects are showing up not only in their expanding girth but also in their health -- and death -- statistics. American women are particularly sedentary. According to the 2000 National Health Interview Survey, 72 percent of women and 64 percent of men get no regular exercise.
